Award.AwardTitle: Scaling up epizootic dynamics - Linking individual infection to spatial spread of a disease using Bayesian hierarchical approaches
Award.AbstractNarration:
What determines how fast a disease spreads through a population may depend on how fast the disease spreads inside an infected individual so that processes within an individual are important for understanding disease transmission between individuals. Often, disease data are collected at a single scale of reference, such as within the individual, and other scales are ignored. This research will develop statistical methods and models that bring together information across scales ranging from the individual to the landscape. The experimental data used to develop these models will focus on an easily manipulated host-pathogen interaction between the fall armyworm and its lethal pathogen, a baculovirus. The models of transmission dynamics derived from the experimental data will quantify the extent that smaller scale processes affect larger scale dynamics and whether or not ignoring scale matters.

In general, the modeling framework developed can be used to understand disease transmission, forecast transmission probability, and outbreak severity for other diseases including human pathogens. From an agricultural perspective, lethal baculoviruses represent a biological insecticide. This research will aid in their use and development. Additionally, this multidisciplinary project will involve a number of graduate students and postdoctoral researchers. The research conducted will train the next generation of statisticians, ecologists, and pathologists who will strengthen the ideas and methodologies generated from working across these disciplines.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We often view disease and disease processes from a single perspective or a single scale. For example, we will ask, ''how fast does a disease spread through a population?'' Or, ''how fast does a disease spread within an individual?''  The research undertaken during the course of this project examined disease transmission at multiple scales ranging from within the individual to the spread of a disease across the landscape. Our multi-disciplinary research team examined transmission dynamics across multiple scales from two different but overlapping viewpoints -- empirical and theoretical. Thus, during the course of our work, we developed and refined a number of mathematical and statistical models that examined how variability amongst individuals or populations affected disease outbreaks. Our experimental data showed how variability impacted the transmission process from an empirical viewpoint. These data were also used to refine and further develop the models mentioned above. In turn, the models helped to refine the experimental process.  Together, these two approaches worked in concert.

Our experimental system consisted of an easily manipulated host-pathogen interaction between the fall armyworm (Spodoptera frugiperda), an agricultural pest, and its lethal pathogen, a baculovirus. Since horizontal transmission of the disease occurs when a healthy fall armyworm larva consumes the virus while feeding on leaf tissue, we used soybean (Glycine max) at the base of this tri-trophic interaction between a pathogen, its herbivore host, and the plant on which the herbivore feeds. Soybeans varieties vary in the ability to decrease feeding by herbivores via a number of different chemical and physical defenses. For some varieties of soybeans, these defenses increase after some part of the plant has been chewed on by an herbivore.  We showed during the course of this project that these induced defenses at the individual level affect fall armyworm feeding rates, fall armyworm development, and baculovirus efficacy.  At the population level, these induced defenses actually decreased viral transmission in the field. By examining these processes at a variety of scales, we gain a fuller insight into how within-individual dynamics affects population-level dynamics. Overall, we demonstrated that one cannot view host-pathogen interactions alone without taking into consideration the environmental context in which they happen.

Outside of the empirical research focused on these tri-trophic dynamics, the work also contributed to other areas.  From a modeling perspective, we sought to develop both new statistical and mathematical models to understand disease dynamics across multiple scales. The modeling framework was developed with regard to our empirical study system but was also used to understand disease transmission processes outside of the specific empirical system and examine long-term population dynamics.  From an agricultural perspective, baculoviruses can be used a biological insecticide. This research will aid in their use and development.  Thus, while focusing on a particular study system, the insights gained were much broader.

Besides the outcomes listed above, the research contributed to the STEM training of a number of up-and-coming scientists whether they were undergraduate students, graduate students, or post-doctoral scholars. We believe that we have had a hand in training the next generation of scholars and researchers who will tackle problems in disease ecology, agriculture, and model development.
